title: Redox Reactions: Disproportionation and Agent Identification
subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Disproportionation is a redox reaction in which the same element in a single reactant is simultaneously oxidised and reduced. Which of the following reactions is an example of disproportionation?
questions.explanation: In Cl₂ + H₂O → HCl + HClO, chlorine (oxidation state 0 in Cl₂) is simultaneously reduced to -1 in HCl and oxidised to +1 in HClO. This satisfies the definition of disproportionation. The other options involve different elements undergoing oxidation and reduction.

questions.question: Disproportionation occurs when atoms of the same element in identical initial oxidation states undergo both oxidation and reduction in the same reaction. In 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂, what happens to oxygen?
options: Some oxygen atoms are oxidised, others are reduced
Oxygen atoms undergo no change in oxidation state
questions.explanation: In H₂O₂, all oxygen atoms start with oxidation state -1. In the products, oxygen in H₂O has oxidation state -2 (reduction) while oxygen in O₂ has oxidation state 0 (oxidation). Since the same element undergoes both processes, this is disproportionation.

questions.question: Consider the reaction: 2KMnO₄ + 10KI + 8H₂SO₄ → 2MnSO₄ + 6K₂SO₄ + 5I₂ + 8H₂O. Which substance is the oxidising agent?
questions.explanation: KMnO₄ contains Mn in +7 state (MnO₄⁻). In products, Mn is +2 (MnSO₄), so Mn gains electrons (reduction). The substance that is reduced is the oxidising agent.

questions.question: In the reaction 2KMnO₄ + 10KI + 8H₂SO₄ → 2MnSO₄ + 6K₂SO₄ + 5I₂ + 8H₂O, what is the change in oxidation state of iodine?
questions.explanation: In KI, iodine is I⁻ with oxidation state -1. In I₂, iodine has oxidation state 0. Change: -1 → 0 (loss of electrons = oxidation).

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes the roles in the reaction between acidified KMnO₄ and KI?
options: KMnO₄ is oxidised; KI is reduced
KMnO₄ is the reducing agent; KI is the oxidising agent
KMnO₄ is reduced; KI is oxidised
Both KMnO₄ and KI are oxidised
questions.explanation: Mn in KMnO₄ changes from +7 to +2 (gains electrons → reduced). I in KI changes from -1 to 0 (loses electrons → oxidised). KMnO₄ is the oxidising agent; KI is the reducing agent.

questions.question: What is the oxidation state of manganese in KMnO₄ and in MnSO₄ respectively?
questions.explanation: In KMnO₄: K = +1, O = -2 (×4 = -8). Let Mn = x: +1 + x - 8 = 0 → x = +7. In MnSO₄: SO₄²⁻ has -2 charge, so Mn = +2.

questions.question: Disproportionation is a reaction where the same element is both oxidised and reduced. In the reaction Cl₂ + 2NaOH → NaCl + NaClO + H₂O, what are the oxidation states of chlorine in NaCl and NaClO?
questions.explanation: Chlorine starts with oxidation state 0 in Cl₂. In NaCl, Cl = -1 (reduction). In NaClO: Na = +1, O = -2, so Cl = +1 (oxidation). The same element (chlorine) undergoes both processes → disproportionation.

questions.question: When acidified potassium manganate(VII) reacts with potassium iodide, a brown solution forms. What causes the brown colour?
questions.explanation: Iodide ions (I⁻) are oxidised to iodine (I₂), which dissolves in water to give a brown solution. This is a characteristic test for oxidising agents using KI.

questions.question: Which half-equation correctly shows the reduction of manganate(VII) ions in acidic conditions?
questions.explanation: In acidic conditions, MnO₄⁻ (Mn⁺⁷) is reduced to Mn²⁺. Balanced half-equation: MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O. (Option A is for neutral conditions; Option C is for alkaline conditions.)

questions.question: Disproportionation occurs when the same element in identical starting conditions undergoes both oxidation and reduction. In 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂, what is the ratio of oxygen atoms that are oxidised to those that are reduced?
questions.explanation: In 2H₂O₂ (4 oxygen atoms total, all at -1), two oxygen atoms form H₂O (oxidation state -2 → reduction) and two oxygen atoms form O₂ (oxidation state 0 → oxidation). Ratio of oxidised : reduced oxygen atoms = 2 : 2 = 1 : 1.
